718915f-a.text:
Broadway, City Hall Park, Broadway and Ann Street
1860

717135f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the
original Astor House occuping the entire block front.
Ewing Galloway  About 1874

717121f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Vesey (right) and Ann (left) Streets, showing prominently the Western Union Building and the spire of Trinity Church. In the right foreground is a portion of the Astor House, facing St. Pauls Chapel. On the extreme left appears the entrance to the New York Herald Building.
1880.
Brown Brothers.

717122f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Vesey (right) and Ann (left) Streets, showing prominently the Western Union Building and the spire of Trinity Church. On the right (foreground) appears a portion of the old Astor House
facing St. Pauls Chapel.
1880.
Brown Brothers.

717132f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from and including Vesey, to and including Dey Streets, showimg.a portion of the Astor House, St. Pauls P.E. Chapel and the Western Union Building. On the extreme left appears a portion of the New York Herald Building (part of present site of St. Paul
Building).
About 1880.

717137f.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Vesey Street, suowing prominently the old Astor House, built 1832, occupying the entire block frontage to Barclay Street. Early records inform us that this site was an encampment for negro slaves in 1780. Numbers of these died of smallpox and were buried where the Sun (formerly A. T. Stewart) Building stands at the N. E. corner of Broadway and Chambers Street. The Woolworth Building was erected in 1912 and the Transportation Building in 1926. The latter at the far corner, while the former in the block above.
About 1890
Thru New York Historical

717120f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at Vesey Street, as viewed southwestward on Park Row and showing St. Pauls P.E. Chapel and a portion of the old Astor House. Across the nave of the Chapel appears buildings that line the south side of Fulton Street, west from Broadway to Church Street. Note the horse drawn cars in the foreground,a junction point of several lines.
About 1891.
Brown Brothers.

717139f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Street's, showing the old Astor House, as photographed from the
St. Paul Building.
About 1895

717140f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Vesey Street(left, not shown). Detailed from left to right are, the Astor Pouse, the Postal Telegraph and the Home Life Insurance Co. Bldgs., the Thoe Leather 3ank, the Sun Bldg. (formerly A. T. Stewarts) and the old U. S. General Post Office. The latter is at the apex formed by the convergence of Park Row with Broadway at this point. This photo is an enlargement from an original lantern slide.
About 1895-7
Gift of Russell Freeman
New York Public Library

717127f-a.text:
220 Broadway, at the S. E. corner of Ann Street, showing the 25 storied St. Paul Building. On the left is an eastward view on Ann Street, from Park Row, an arterial thoroughfare that begins at this point. Note the ornate National Park Bank at the right. This is obstructed by a corner of St. Pauls Chapel.
1897
Copyright 1897
C. C. Langill, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RICRTE UNENOwN

717141f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the old Astor House, erected in 1832. The far corner of this site will be utilized for the 44 story Transportation Building in 1926. In 1912 in the block above will rise the towering Woolworth Building. At the right margin appears a glimpse of this site.
About 1900
International News Service
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RITBTE UNENDwN

717148f-a.text:
Broacway, north from near Vesey Street, showing more of the west side of the thoroughfare, On the extreme left is part of the old Astor House. The block front just north of it was repraced later with the Woolworth Building.
MAY BE REPPODCED  about 1900
Ng2 157

717133f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the Astor House (erected in 1832). The view is southward from Barclay Street. The foreground half of this building site will be improved with the 44story
Transportation Building in 1926.
May 9, 1913
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717146f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the old Astor House of 1832. To the right is a glimpse of the Woolworth Building in the block above.
1913

Credit line imperative

717149f.text:
Broadway, at the N. W. corner of Vesey Street, showing the southerly half of the old Astor House demolished. A new 7-story Astor Building was erected here. The remaining half will subsequently be removed for the 44-storied Transportation Building. Beyond is the base of the Woolworth Building. On the right appears the old Post Office. This is at the anex of Cty Hall Park that is formed by the convergence of Park Row at Broadway. In 1939 this structure was removed and the park restored to its original
form.
November 1, 1913
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717110f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Vesey (right foreground) and Ann (left, not shown) Streets, showing a portion of St. Pauls P. E. Chapel facing the National Park Bank. These structures are on opposing sides of this thru-fare.
General Electric Company  1924

717125f-a.text:
217 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Vesey Sbreet, showing the Astor House Building, a structure that replaced the southern portion of the old Astor
House.
About 1924
Ehnickerbocker Photo Service

723780f.text:
.12 to 30 Vesey Street, north side, west from, but not including
Broadway (right), to Church Street (left).
June 1926.
Brown Bros.

723781f-a.text:
A general view westward on Vesey Street from Broadway, as seen from the St. Paul Building (Broadway at the S.E. corner of Ann Street) and showing the spire of St. Pauls P.E. Chapel silhouetted against the cemetery and frinity offices at its rear. Prominently shown is the New York Telephone Co. Building (West Street) of which appears the Washington Street side. Dimly observable is the New Jersey shore as seen across the Hudson (North) River. Note the five story loft buildings standing between the Sixth Ave. (Church Street) and Ninth Ave. (Greenwich Street) elevated and overshadowed by the Underwood Building. Today (1937) the downtown United States Post Office rises on this site.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.

717130f.text:
220 Broadway, at the S. E. corner of Ann Street, showing the lower portions of the 25 story St. Paul Building. On the rtght is a partial view of the National Park Bank, lying between Ann
and Fulton Street's.
About 1930
American Studio, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RICCRT8 UNENONN

717114f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from Vesey to Fulton Streets. Shown at this location is St. Paul's P.E. Chapel and grounds.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

723782f-a.text:
Vesey Street, west from Broadway to West Street, showing the U.S. Post office (white building) and beyond, the N.Y. Telephone Building. A portion of St. Pauls (P.E.) Cemetery is seen on the south side of the street, extending to Church Street. Also shown are portions of the Sixth Ave. and Ninth Ave. Elevated Lines running at this point on
Church and Greenwich Streets, respectively.
April 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

717178f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey Street (left) to Park Place (right), as viewed across City Hall Park, from the Municipal Building. In the center is Barclay Street. This separates the Transportation Building from the dominant Woolworth Building. Vesey Street performs this function for the vague St. Paul Chapel
and the Astor Building.
April 1940
George D. Chinn

717147f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Vesey (left) to Barclay (right) Streets, showing the Astor House, built in 1832 and opened in 1836 by Boyden, a hotel keeper from Boston. It was reopened September 1, 1875 by F.J. Allan and A.J. Dunn. The portion at the N.W. corner of Vesey Street was demolished and is today (1937) the site of the Astor Building, No. 217 Broadway. On this site in 1780 there was an encampment of Negro slaves, enticed by Lord Dunmore from Virginia. Large numbers died from small pox and were buried in the ground later occupied by Stewarts (Department Store) at Chambers Street and Broadway.
Date---f
Eugane L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, at a later date and showing a more extensive view to and including Park Place. Note the portion of the Astor House still standing. This was taken down in March 1926 and there upon was erected the 44Ntorv Transportation Bcilding, No. 225 Broadway, at the S.W. corner of Barclay Street. The Woolworth Building occupies the block between Barely
Street and Park Place.
May 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

717147f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Vesey (left) to Barclay (right) Streets, showing the Astor House, built in 1832 and opened in 1836 by Boyden, a hotel keeper from Boston. It was reopened September 1, 1875 by F.J. Allan and A.J. Dunn. The portion at the N.W. corner of Vesey Street was demolished and is today (1937) the site of the Astor Building, No. 217 Broadway. On this site in 1780 there was an encampment of Negro slaves, enticed by Lord Dunmore from Virginia. Large numbers died from small pox and were buried in the ground later occupied by Stewarts (Department Store) at Chambers Street and Broadway.
Date---f
Eugane L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, at a later date and showing a more extensive view to and including Park Place. Note the portion of the Astor House still standing. This was taken down in March 1926 and there upon was erected the 44Ntorv Transportation Bcilding, No. 225 Broadway, at the S.W. corner of Barclay Street. The Woolworth Building occupies the block between Barely
Street and Park Place.
May 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
